qas.question: Who granted money to Eton for a sports complex in 1995?
When did the Thames Valley Athletics Centre open?
For what did the college pay a substancial sum and donate 4.5 hectres of land?

answers.text: in return for exclusive use of the facilities during the daytime only

qas.question: How many cricket squares does Eton have?
How many swimming pools are located within Eton?
In what year was the National Lottery established?
When was Safe Neighbourhoods Unit founded?
How much do UK councils spend on youth services each year?
Who led the National Lottery in 1995?
Who led the UK Sports Council in 1995?

context: In <b5_0><b6_0>1995<b6_0/><b5_0/> <a0_0>the National Lottery<a0_0/> granted money for a <b7_0>£4.6m<b7_0/> sports complex, to add to Eton's existing facilities of <a4_0>two<a4_0/> swimming pools, <a3_0>30<a3_0/> cricket squares, 24 football, rugby and hockey pitches and a gym. The College paid £200,000 and contributed 4.5 hectares of land <a2_0>in return for exclusive use of the facilities during the daytime only<a2_0/>. The UK Sports Council defended the deal on the grounds that the whole community would benefit, while the bursar claimed that Windsor, Slough and Eton Athletic Club was "deprived" because local people (who were not pupils at the College) did not have a world-class running track and facilities to train with. <b8_0><b9_0>Steve Osborn<b9_0/><b8_0/>, director of the Safe Neighbourhoods Unit, described the decision as "staggering" given the background of a substantial reduction in youth services by councils across the country, a matter over which, however, neither the College nor the UK Sports Council, had any control. The facility, which became the Thames Valley Athletics Centre, opened in <a1_0>April 1999<a1_0/>.
